question: Write a diary entry from Eugenia’s perspective about the day she witnessed 'He' rolling on the ground beside her and what followed.
gold_answer: Diary, Today was quite unexpected. As I stood by the roadside, 'He' suddenly rolled on the ground beside me. I was startled, unsure how to react. Bray soon arrived, and I held out my slim hand to him, hoping to steady myself. The air was tense; the lady nearby seemed sorry for 'He', who eventually caught hold of a woman's body—Sophy, I believe.
llm_answer:
June 3rd, later, same damp sheet of paper.

I write by the last of the candle, my hand still trembling so the ink spiders across the page.  This morning I believed nothing could shake me after the winter I have spent in this swamp-school—yet the earth itself slipped to-day.

I had taken the children to the foot of the hill for their botany lesson; the air was thick and humming.  We were gathering mint when I heard the thud—soft, like a sack of meal dropped from a cart.  I turned and saw HIM—yes, the same gentleman who boards at the Moffatts’—sprawled on the grass not ten paces off.  His coat was flung wide, his cravat gone, and he was rolling slowly, deliberately, as if the ground were a bed and he sought a cool place for his burning skin.  His eyes were shut, the lashes beating against the noon sun; every few seconds a shudder ran through him, the kind I have seen in Sister Ruth’s consumptive pupils.  Yet his face—oh, his face—wore an expression of such fierce relief it frightened me more than pain would have done.

The little ones clutched my skirts.  I told them to stay, and went forward alone.  When I knelt he opened his eyes and fixed them on me—blue, unclouded, as if he had been waiting.  “Miss Angeline,” he said—he still calls me by the school-name though I have asked him to use Eugenia—“I am not drunk, not mad.  I am only hot inside, and the earth is cold.  Let me lie here one minute more.”  His voice was courteous, but there was underneath it a tremor of laughter, or perhaps sobs; I could not tell.  I asked if I should fetch Mr. Moffatt or the doctor.  He caught my wrist—gently, yet I felt the furnace-heat of his palm—and said, “If you bring any soul, I shall have to rise and walk, and I cannot walk yet.  Stay with me yourself, or go away and forget you saw me.”

I stayed.  The children, wide-eyed, sat in the grass and began to play with their sprigs of mint as if a grown man rolling on the ground were the most natural thing in the world.  Perhaps to them it is.  I watched the pulse in his throat; it beat like a trapped bird.  After a little he turned his face to the turf and whispered, “I used to do this when I was small—press my heart to the ground until the fever went back into the earth.  My mother let me.  She said the planet could bear what we cannot.”  Then he was quiet, and I heard the insects again.

When the spell passed he rose, brushed the grass from his coat, and looked at me as if we had been praying together.  “You will not speak of this,” he said—not a question, but a plea.  I promised.  He bowed, walked over the hill, and disappeared toward the Darlington works.  I know now what the steel-men mean when they speak of the hidden heat in an ingot: the outside cool enough to touch, the inside white as stars.  I have seen that heat in a human creature to-day.

Sister Ruth says I study too much solitude; perhaps I do.  Yet I would not have missed this hour for every quiet room I ever longed for.  I do not know his sorrow, but I felt it pass into the ground beneath us, and the grass is still warm where he lay.  I will keep my word and tell no one—only, I have written it here so the memory will not burn a hole through me.

The candle gutters.  Outside, the frogs begin.  I wonder if the earth feels lighter to-night for what it took from him, or heavier for what it keeps.
